sen.j: 葛城御県神社（かつらぎみあがたじんじゃ）は、奈良県葛城市葛木（旧新庄町）にある神社である。
sen.e: Katsuragimiagata-jinja Shrine is in Katsuragi, Katsuragi City, Nara Prefecture (former Shinjo-cho).
Katsuragimiagata-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Katsuragi, Katsuragi City, Nara Prefecture (former Shinjo-cho).
Katsuragimiagata-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Katsuragi, Katsuragi City, Nara Prefecture (former Shinjo-cho).

sen.j: 式内社で、旧社格は村社。
sen.e: It is shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws), and the old classification of shrine is sonsha (a village shrine).
It is shikinai-sha (shrine listed in the Engishiki laws) and ranked as a sonsha (village shrine) under the old shrine classification system..
It is shikinai-sha (shrine listed in the Engishiki laws) and ranked as a sonsha (village shrine) under the old shrine classification system..

sen.j: 大和国に6つある御縣神社の1つである。
sen.e: It is one of the six miagata-jinja Shrines in Yamato Province.
It is one of the six miagata-jinja Shrines in Yamato Province.
It is one of the six miagata-jinja Shrines in Yamato Province.
Enshrined deity
Enshrined Deities
Enshrined Deities

sen.j: 劔根命を主祭神とし、ニニギを配祀する。
sen.e: Tsurugine no Mikoto is the shusaijin (main enshrined deities), and it enshrines Ninigi as associated deity.
Tsurugine no Mikoto is the shusaijin (main enshrined deities), Ninigi is enshrined as an associated deity.
Tsurugine no Mikoto is the shusaijin (main enshrined deities), Ninigi is enshrined as an associated deity.

sen.j: ただし、元々の祭神は天津日高日子番能瓊瓊杵命であり、劔根命は明治5年に祀られたものである。
sen.e: But the original enshrined deity is Amatsuhiko Hikohono Ninigi no Mikoto, and Tsurugine no Mikoto was enshrined in 1872.
sen.cmt: 天津日高日子番能瓊瓊杵命ですが、英語読みをした時にどこを大文字にするのかがわかりませんでした。
sen.e: However the original enshrined deity was Amatsuhiko Hikohono Ninigi no Mikoto, with Tsurugine no Mikoto being enshrined in 1872.
However the original enshrined deity was Amatsuhiko Hikohono Ninigi no Mikoto, with Tsurugine no Mikoto being enshrined in 1872.

sen.j: 劔根命は、日本書紀に神武東征の論功行将により葛城国造に任じられたと記される人物である。
sen.e: In Nihon-shoki, Tsurugine no Mikoto is said to be a person who was appointed Kazuragi no Kuni no miyatsukoby the grant of honors according to the merits of Jinmu tosei (Eastern expedition of the Emperor Jinmu).
sen.cmt: 「論功行将」は「論功行賞」ではないでしょうか。
sen.e: In Nihon-shoki, Tsurugine no Mikoto is said to be a person who was appointed governor of Kazuragi Provincein honor of his exploits during the Jinmu tosei (Eastern expedition of Emperor Jinmu).
In Nihon-shoki, Tsurugine no Mikoto is said to be a person who was appointed governor of Kazuragi Provincein honor of his exploits during the Jinmu tosei (Eastern expedition of Emperor Jinmu).
History
History
History

sen.j: 創立の年代は不詳である。
sen.e: It is unknown when this shrine was built.
t is unknown when this shrine was founded.
t is unknown when this shrine was founded.

sen.j: 元々は現在地より100メートル東に鎮座していた。
sen.e: Originally, it was enshrined 100m east to the present place.
It was originally located 100m east of its present location.
It was originally located 100m east of its present location.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳に「大和国葛下郡 葛木御縣神社」と記載され、大社に列している。
sen.e: In Engishiki jinmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan), it is mentioned as "Katsuragimiagata-jinja Shrine, Katsuraginoshimo County, Yamato Province", and ranked as taisha (grand shrine).
In the Engishiki Jinmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan), it is described as 'Katsuragimiagata-jinja Shrine, Katsuraginoshimo County, Yamato Province', and ranked as taisha (grand shrine).
In the Engishiki Jinmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan), it is described as 'Katsuragimiagata-jinja Shrine, Katsuraginoshimo County, Yamato Province', and ranked as taisha (grand shrine).

sen.j: いつの時代からか境内に八王山西光寺が建立され、後に神社の方は衰えた。
sen.e: Out of nowhere, Hachiozan Saikoji-Temple was built in the precincts, and later, the shrine declined.
sen.cmt: 「いつの時代からか」が上手く訳せませんでした。
sen.e: Hachiozan Saikoji-Temple was built within the shrine precinct at one point and the shrine subsequently went into decline.
Hachiozan Saikoji-Temple was built within the shrine precinct at one point and the shrine subsequently went into decline.

sen.j: 1601年（慶長6年）、当地の領主桑山氏は諸鍬神社 (愛西市)を三才山（伝飯豊天皇陵）に勧請し、それに当社を合祀した。
sen.e: In 1601, the feudal load KUWAYAMA made a branch shrine of Morokuwa-jinja Shrine (in present Aisai City) for a deity in Misayama (Mausoleum of Emperor Iitoyo, unconfirmed) and then enshrined Katsuragimiagata-jinja Shrine together.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1601, the feudal load KUWAYAMA made a branch shrine of Morokuwa-jinja Shrine (in present Aisai City) for a deity in Misayama (Mausoleum of Emperor Iitoyo, unconfirmed) and then enshrined Katsuragimiagata-jinja Shrine together.

In 1601, the feudal load KUWAYAMA made a branch shrine of Morokuwa-jinja Shrine (in present Aisai City) for a deity in Misayama (Mausoleum of Emperor Iitoyo, unconfirmed) and then enshrined Katsuragimiagata-jinja Shrine together.

sen.j: 諸桑神社は自らの産土神であり、尾張国海東郡にあった。
sen.e: Morokuwa-jinja Shrine was his ubusunagami (guardian deity of his birthplace) and located in Kaito District, Owari Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Morokuwa-jinja Shrine was his ubusunagami (guardian deity of his birthplace) and located in Kaito District, Owari Province.
Morokuwa-jinja Shrine was his ubusunagami (guardian deity of his birthplace) and located in Kaito District, Owari Province.

sen.j: 1864年（元治元年）、葛城御県神社を諸鍬神社より分離し旧社地に復しようとしたが、その地には西光寺があるため、その西の現在地に遷座した。
sen.e: In 1864, people tried to separate Katsuragimiagata-jinja Shrine from Morokuwa-jinja Shrine, and put it back to where it was, but there was Saiko-ji Temple there, so it was transferred to the west to the temple, to the present place.

In 1864, an attempt was made to separate Katsuragimiagata-jinja Shrine from Morokuwa-jinja Shrine, and return it to where it once stood but Saiko-ji Temple was already standing there so it was transferred to its current site west of the temple.

In 1864, an attempt was made to separate Katsuragimiagata-jinja Shrine from Morokuwa-jinja Shrine, and return it to where it once stood but Saiko-ji Temple was already standing there so it was transferred to its current site west of the temple.

sen.j: 1874年（明治6年）に村社に列格した。
sen.e: In 1874, it became a sonsha (a village shrine).
In 1874, it became a sonsha (a village shrine).
In 1874, it became a sonsha (a village shrine).
